Thankfully no. Most common hallucination for me, when it comes to auditory - is just gibberish noise, no matter where I go. It is annoying, so it makes me very irritable. Never heard voices, but I know some that do. Visuals are very imaginative. However, the most common visual hallucinations in the past year or so have been something very similar to [fregoli delusion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fregoli_delusion), how I experience this is that people that I both know and do not know are either unrecognizable, or really recognizable in someone else. It's hard to explain, but I can give you an example. Last week I took the bus to the psychiatrist, on the bus i saw my sister (it was impossible for her to be there at that time), she went out of the bus, and a couple of minutes later I saw her again sitting somewhere else on the bus. Then I saw her two times, at the same time.

Yes, they are professing Christians (as am I ). 

Overall, they felt that a lot of our local schools had been dumbed down to the level of the lower students, and with homeschooling, each individual child  can be taught at the level they are, and especially in the things they are proficient in. (Not all of us -> <- are good at math for instance)

They also have rescued a child with special needs who had been starved in an orphanage in Bulgaria for years. We adopted her at age 9 and she weighed 10 pounds.  We now have 3 children with special needs, and they do go to classes at School, and that has been working very well.

**Fregoli delusion**

The Fregoli delusion, or the delusion of doubles, is a rare disorder in which a person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes appearance or is in disguise. The syndrome may be related to a brain lesion and is often of a paranoid nature, with the delusional person believing themselves persecuted by the person they believe is in disguise.

A person with the Fregoli delusion can also inaccurately recall places, objects, and events. This disorder can be explained by "associative nodes".
